Exalted on her ebon throne,</br>Sad, silent, gloomy, and alone,</br>Enthusiasm sits;</br>No joy her heavy heart can feel,</br>Woe on her face has set its seal,</br>Her baleful eye, with glances dire,</br>Shoots a fearful, gloomy fire</br>That blasts where e'er it hits.

Behold the spectre waves her wand!</br>Hark!  she calls her dismal band:</br>See!  Ignorance is foremost of the ghastly train,</br>The chief supporter of the tyrant's reign;</br>With error's mist before her eyes,</br>She trembling creeps or wildly flies;</br>Alternate in her looks appear</br>Presumption bold and abject fear.</br>Next Superstition stalks along,</br>Round her delusive phantoms throng,</br>Now demons grim with snaky hair,</br>Now beauteous forms of painted air;</br>But nought her anxious, clouded aspect chears,</br>She starts at those and these she boding fears.

And look where woe-worn Melancholy slowly moves;</br>In her gloomy, callous face</br>Of no soft sympathy the trace;—</br>Sad Solitude, alone, she loves:</br>Round she casts a heedless eye,</br>Then stops, and heaves a mournful sigh,—</br>To heaven she looks, but yet prefers no prayer,</br>For all is hopeless quite, all fixed black despair.

Whence those horrid cries?</br>To break her chain that raging spectre tries!</br>Whence that furious strife!</br>'Tis desperate Madness struggling for the knife!</br>From her frenzy'd eye</br>Vivid lightnings fly—</br>Her shackled hands she cannot disengage,</br>And now she sits in the fierce gloom of disappointed Rage.

But see, with visage pale and brow severe,</br>Stern Inquisition drags her victim there:</br>The woe-struck wretch, in deep despair,</br>Attempts not a persuasive prayer;</br>The hag obdurate, never hears</br>The suppliant's sigh or feels his tears;</br>Each happy, fond connection o'er,</br>His sad remembrance pains the more:</br>Snatch'd from his friends, he knows their fears,</br>Their boding hearts, their flowing tears;</br>He sees his lovely partner of each care</br>In wild distraction rend her hair;</br>Her frighted infant round her clings,</br>Heedless, away the lovely babe she flings;</br>Her piercing cries distract his madd'ning brain,</br>Nor can his trembling knees his throbbing blush sustain,</br>Senseless he falls, his clanking chains resound,</br>His grinding teeth imprint the shaking ground—</br>Again he opens a despairing eye,</br>Or if he hopes, — 'tis speedily to die.—</br>The Monster with inexorable ire,</br>Prepares the rack and lights the lingering fire.

Ha!  see where dreadful Massacre appears,</br>From earth to heav'n her hideous form she rears;</br>Where e'er she rolls her baneful eyes,</br>She spreads dismay and wild surprize—</br>The harpy Fiend prepares for flight;</br>Her huge, stretch'd, shadowy wings turn day to night:</br>Sear'd in her heart is pity's source,</br>Havock and desolation mark her course—</br>Nor age, nor infancy, nor sex she spares,</br>The blooming maid, the helpless babe, the nerveless sire she tears.</br>The mingled heaps she sits with exultation o'er,</br>Her heavy pinions drench'd with reeking gore;</br>To heaven she raises a presumptive eye,</br>Its favour claims and grins a horrid joy.

Sweet Religion, chearful mild,</br>Pleasure's source, and Reason's child,</br>Come, array'd in heavenly sheen,</br>Come and chear the dismal scene;</br>Hope, bright beaming, in thine eye,</br>Bid Despair and Horror fly:</br>Let us see thy beauteous face,</br>Come and dwell with human race;</br>Be but thou our helpmate dear,</br>We'll begin our heaven here.</br>
